DescriptionChanged.old_description:
The -n/--author-name and -e/--author-email parameters seem broken / like they don't do anything.

INVESTIGATION RESULTS:
The parameters are actually working correctly. They set the git commit author for issue events.

To verify this works:
1. Make an edit with custom author: git-issue edit <ID> --priority high -n 'Test Author' -e 'test@example.com' --no-editor
2. Check the commit author: git log refs/git-issue/issues/<ID> --pretty=format:'%h %an <%ae> %s'

The CLI output doesn't show the event author in the 'show' command, but the git commits are correctly authored.
DescriptionChanged.new_description:
The -n/--author-name and -e/--author-email parameters seem broken / like they don't do anything.

INVESTIGATION RESULTS:
The parameters work when combined with actual changes, but there's a usability issue:

PROBLEM: When users run 'git-issue edit <ID> --author-name "XYZ" --no-editor' without specifying other changes, the command reports 'No changes made' and doesn't do anything.

EXPECTATION: Users might reasonably expect that specifying author parameters would result in some kind of action or at least a different message explaining that no field changes were specified.

CURRENT BEHAVIOR: Author parameters are only applied when there are actual field changes (title, description, status, priority, labels, assignee).

POSSIBLE SOLUTIONS:
1. Better error message when only author params are specified
2. Allow author-only changes to update some metadata
3. Documentation clarification about when author params are used
